Situation1: Include each other in social activities and outings when possible.
Expectation2: Ensure compliance with safety and regulatory standards
Situation2: A recently updated standard will apply to the upcoming release, and evidence of conformity is required
Story:
I stared at my phone, my brother’s message lighting up the screen: “Don’t forget, you promised to come to the concert tonight. Everyone’s counting on you.” I could almost hear his voice, half-joking, half-serious, reminding me how much it meant to him that I show up, that I be part of the group. We’d been working on building a better relationship, making time for each other, and I knew skipping out would set us back.

But at my desk, the new engineering standard document glared at me from my monitor. The company’s next product release was in two days, and the updated safety regulations were non-negotiable. My manager had made it clear: “We need documented proof of compliance before launch. No exceptions.” The pressure was immense—if I missed something, the consequences could be severe.

I felt the weight of both worlds pressing in. My brother wanted me to be present, to show I cared. My team needed me to ensure everything was safe and up to code. I sat there, torn, the clock ticking, knowing I couldn’t be in two places at once.
